conversation.text: Would you like to learn how to make hash browns?
Yes, what do I need?
Russet potatoes, or other high starch potatoes
evidence: Russet potatoes, or other potatoes with a high starch content, work best for hash browns.

conversation.text: What is the first step?
Wash and peel the potatoes, use cold water when washing
evidence: Wash the potatoes well in cold water, then peel using a small knife or a vegetable peeler

conversation.text: What do I use to peel the potatoes?
you can use a vegetable peeler, or a small knife
evidence: a small knife or a vegetable peeler

conversation.text: I will use a peeler
Are you ready to move on?
Yes, what is the next step?
Shred the potatoes into a towel-lined bowl
evidence: Line a bowl with a clean dishtowel, then shred the potatoes directly into the towel-lined bowl, using a cheese grater

conversation.text: What do I use to shred the potatoes?
A cheese grater works well
Okay, what is the next step?
squeeze out as much moisture as possible from the shredded potatoes
Why do I squeeze out moisture?
In order to get crispy hash browns
evidence: This is the most important step in achieving crispy (rather than mushy) hash browns

conversation.text: That makes sense, what do I do next?
Heat a skillet over a medium-high heat and add butter to the pan
evidence: Heat a large skillet pan (preferably cast iron) over a medium-high heat. Add the butter to the pan and allow to melt.

conversation.text: What sort of skillet works best?
cast iron is preferable
Okay. What do I do with the butter?
allow the butter to melt
What do I do next?
Add the shredded potatoes and toss to coat with butter
evidence: add the dry, shredded potatoes to the pan and toss to coat with butter.

conversation.text: Do I need to add anything else
You can add salt and pepper to taste
How long do I cook the hash browns for?
3-4 minutes on one side, then 2-3 minutes on the other
evidence: Cook for 3-4 minutes on the first side, flip, then cook for 2-3 minutes on the other side
Cook for 3-4 minutes on the first side, flip, then cook for 2-3 minutes on the other side

conversation.text: How do I flip the hash brown?
flatten the hash brown with a spatula and use it to flip
evidence: flatten it using a spatula to maximize contact with the hot pan

conversation.text: What colour should the hash brown be?
the hash brown should be golden brown and crispy
evidence: The hash brown potatoes are ready when each side is crisp and golden brown

conversation.text: Is that all the steps?
Yes, your hash brown is ready to be served
evidence: Slide the hash brown from the pan, or lift using a large spatula

conversation.text: What do you recommend serving with my hash brown?
Hot sauce or ketcup, or alongside bacon and eggs
evidence: Serve on its own, with hot sauce or ketchup, or alongside bacon and eggs for a top notch breakfast

conversation.text: Okay, that sounds delicious
Enjoy your crispy hash brown
Thank you, I can't wait

procedure.description: Wash the potatoes well in cold water, then peel using a small knife or a vegetable peeler. Russet potatoes, or other potatoes with a high starch content, work best for hash browns.
Line a bowl with a clean dishtowel, then shred the potatoes directly into the towel-lined bowl, using a cheese grater.

You must squeeze out as much moisture as possible from the shredded potatoes. This is the most important step in achieving crispy (rather than mushy) hash browns. To do this, gather the corners of the dishtowel containing the shredded potatoes and twist the neck until you form a tight package. Continue twisting the cloth and squishing the potato in your fist until you've squeezed as much liquid as you can from the potato. Alternatively, you can try squeezing the moisture from the potatoes using a potato ricer. You do not need to force the potatoes through the ricer, simply use it to press out the moisture.

Heat a large skillet pan (preferably cast iron) over a medium-high heat. Add the butter to the pan and allow to melt. Once the butter has melted, add the dry, shredded potatoes to the pan and toss to coat with butter. Season with salt and pepper.

Once the potato has been coated with butter, flatten it using a spatula to maximize contact with the hot pan. It should be no more than 1/2 an inch thick. Cook for 3-4 minutes on the first side, flip, then cook for 2-3 minutes on the other side. The hash brown potatoes are ready when each side is crisp and golden brown.

Slide the hash brown from the pan, or lift using a large spatula. Cut it into halves or quarters, if necessary. Serve on its own, with hot sauce or ketchup, or alongside bacon and eggs for a top notch breakfast.
